text: ਜਬ ਉਸ ਕਉ ਕੋਈ ਦੇਵੈ ਮਾਨੁ ॥

translation.text: When someone tries to appease her,

transliteration.text: jab us kau kōī dēvai mān .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Guru Arjan Dev
author.description:
Guru Arjan Dev [1563 - 1606] was the fifth Guru of the Sikhs, born at Goindval. He was the youngest of the three sons of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Sikh Guru.

Guru Arjan Dev finished the construction of the Harimandir Sahib, the Golden Temple, and compiled the first Sikh scripture, known as the Adi Granth. Shortly after he became the first martyr of the Sikh religion, which formed a turning point in the development of the faith.

translation.text: then she takes pride in herself.

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Guru Arjan Dev

text: ਜਬ ਉਸ ਕਉ ਕੋਈ ਮਨਿ ਪਰਹਰੈ ॥

translation.text: But when someone puts her out of his thoughts,

transliteration.text: jab us kau kōī man paraharai .

The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. text: ਵਡੇ ਭਾਗ ਹੋਵਹਿ ਤਉ ਪਾਈਐ ਬਿਨੁ ਜਿਹਵਾ ਕਿਆ ਜਾਣੈ ਸੁਆਦੁ ॥੧॥ ਰਹਾਉ ॥

translation.text: One who is blessed with high destiny, obtains it. Without a tongue, how can one know the taste? ||1||Pause||

In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Guru Arjan Dev
author.description:
Guru Arjan Dev [1563 - 1606] was the fifth Guru of the Sikhs, born at Goindval. He was the youngest of the three sons of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Sikh Guru.

Guru Arjan Dev finished the construction of the Harimandir Sahib, the Golden Temple, and compiled the first Sikh scripture, known as the Adi Granth. Shortly after he became the first martyr of the Sikh religion, which formed a turning point in the development of the faith.

text: ਰਸਕਿ ਰਸਕਿ ਗੁਣ ਗਾਵਹਿ ਹਰਿ ਜਨ ਅਪਨੈ ਗੁਰਦੇਵਿ ਨਿਵਾਜਾ ॥੧॥ ਰਹਾਉ ॥

translation.text: The Lord's humble servants sing His Glorious Praises with love and delight; they are honored by the Divine Guru. ||1||Pause||

transliteration.text: rasak rasak gun gāvah har jan apanai guradēv nivājā .1. rahāu .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

translation.text: My pre-ordained destiny has been activated;

The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. translation.text: In the Saadh Sangat, the Company of the Holy, my aversion is gone.

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. text: ਮਨੁ ਤਨੁ ਰਾਤੋ ਹਰਿ ਕੈ ਰੰਗਿ ॥੨॥

translation.text: My mind and body are imbued with love for the Lord. ||2||

transliteration.text: man tan rātō har kai rang .2.

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

translation.text: The Merciful Savior Lord has saved me.

The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. text: ਨਾ ਕਿਛੁ ਸੇਵਾ ਨਾ ਕਿਛੁ ਘਾਲ ॥

translation.text: I have no service or work to my credit.

transliteration.text: nā kish sēvā nā kish ghāl .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. translation.text: In His Mercy, God has taken pity on me;

text: ਸੁਣਿ ਸੁਣਿ ਉਪਜਿਓ ਮਨ ਮਹਿ ਚਾਉ ॥

translation.text: Listening, listening to His Praises, joy has welled up within my mind.

transliteration.text: sun sun upajiō man mah chāu .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. text: ਆਠ ਪਹਰ ਹਰਿ ਕੇ ਗੁਣ ਗਾਉ ॥

translation.text: Twenty-four hours a day, I sing the Glorious Praises of the Lord.

transliteration.text: āth pahar har kē gun gāu .

The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. text: ਸੁਖ ਸਾਗਰ ਪੂਰਨ ਪਰਮੇਸਰੁ ਹਰਿ ਨ ਚੇਤਿਓ ਮਨ ਮਾਹੀ ॥੧॥ ਰਹਾਉ ॥

translation.text: You do not remember in your mind the ocean of peace, the perfect Transcendent Lord God. ||1||Pause||

transliteration.text: sukh sāgar pūran paramēsar har n chētiō man māhī .1. rahāu .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

translation.text: Nectar seems bitter to you, and poison is sweet.

The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. translation.text: Such is your condition, you faithless cynic, which I have seen with my own eyes.

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

translation.text: You are fond of falsehood, fraud and egotism.
